Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical Insights into Chemical Functionalization of Carbon Nanotubes: from Chirality Separation to Photoexcited Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Svetlana V Kilina (North Dakota State University Fargo), Dmitri S Kilin (University of South Dakota) and Andrei Kryjevski (North Dakota State University Fargo) are supported in an award co-funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program, the Office of the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) and the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods (CTMC) program. The project is to use computational techniques to investigate carbon nanotubes (CNTs), which are small tubes with carbon connected together. Series of carbon-carbon bonds may spiral around the axis of the tube, and different spiraling rates indicate different types of CNTs. The tubes can be decorated with attachments of small organic molecules or polymers (functionalization), and the choices of which attachments and where can be customized so as to design, for example, what light comes out and how intense it is when an outside light shines on a CNT. Another goal being pursued is to use computations to optimize the molecular decoration for each type of CNT so that chemical processes may be used to separate sticky bundles of CNTs with different rates of spiral, which is the usual way CNTs are produced. Having them separated is ideal for carrying out experiments on CNTs, since experiments can then provide much more discriminating information. The computations for the decorated or functionalized CNTs use both quantum and classical mechanics to interpret and predict properties relevant to experiments. This research aims to facilitate control over the processes of solar energy capture and conversion in functionalized CNTs at the fundamental level, and, thus, will be relevant to chemistry, materials science and engineering.

Functionalization of CNTs by small organic surfactants and conjugated polymers can improve chemical control of their optoelectronic and transport properties as well as offer promise in separation techniques for obtaining CNT samples with similar chiralities. The objective of this research is a systematic theoretical investigation of morphology, electronic structure, and excited state dynamics of CNTs functionalized by different types of conjugated oligomers and polymers. Using computational modeling, the investigators are working to understand fundamental physical processes occurring at organic-inorganic interfaces and governing the operation of CNT-based optoelectronic and photovoltaic devices such as exciton relaxation and recombination, charge transfer, and creation of several excitons from one absorbed photon (carrier multiplication). Density functional theory (DFT) and time dependent DFT (TDDFT) are being used for computing accurate electronic structure and optical response of polymer-CNT hybrids. Furthermore, quantum-classical non-adiabatic dynamics methods are being used to model phonon-mediated dynamics including charge and energy transfer in these systems. A novel approach to the calculation of quantum efficiency, the number of excitons generated by a photon, based on DFT augmented by the many body perturbation theory technique of quantum field theory is being applied to functionalized CNTs. Calculations of a variety of spectroscopic observables permit direct comparison and validation with ultrafast laser spectroscopic data (by other lasboratories) probing the fundamental electronic dynamics in functionalized CNTs. Just as importantly, these calculations provide explicit interpretations and predictions of the key phenomena occurring in the experimental measurements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project generated theoretical insights into the surface chemistry of functionalized single wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) critical to achievements of their full potential for technological applications. PI/coPIs developed methodology that reasonably describes light-driven processes and applied this method to SWCNTs to elucidate the effect of covalent and non-covalent intercalations between the nanotube and different functional molecules on the morphology, electronic structure, and photodynamics. We determined the criteria controlling selective molecule-SWCNT interactions and efficiency of quantum processes, namely, multi-exciton generation and charge transfer, taking place at interfaces and governing the operation of nanotube-based optoelectronic, photovoltaic, and quantum-light devices. 

Last year, the project outcomes were summarized and shared with the scientific community via 5 papers published at high-ranked peer-review journals, plus 3 papers submitted and one book chapter published. Also research results were disseminated to the community via 3 invited talks at scientific conferences and 3 seminar talks at research institutes presented by PI and co-PIs, plus 4 contributed presentations at the local and national scientific conferences reported by our students. PI and coPIs organized the scientific conference closely related to the scope of the project at the Telluride Science Research Center on Nanomaterials: Computation, Theory, and Experiment, where 30 scientists from the US and beyond presented their research results. One postdoc and 3 graduate students worked on this project, with two Ph.D. Dissertations from PI/coPI groups were defended and published by NDSU. Two undergraduate students got their first research experience working on this project, with one started the Graduate School at NDSU in Fall 2018.  

Intellectual Merit. 

 Adapting the developed methodology to SWCNTs functionalized by molecular adducts and comparing results with experimental data, we found that our method is a suitable approach for accurate simulations of light-driven dynamics in nanostructures and their interfaces. To the best of our knowledge, no such comprehensive first-principle methods applicable to describe photodynamics involving multi-exciton processes in nanomaterials with complicated surfaces and interfaces have been previously available to scientific community. Thus, we have advanced the field of computational chemistry and open a new road for more accurate modeling of photoexcited processes in nanomaterials.  

Our research complimented and advanced recent experimental efforts in spectroscopy and chemistry of SWCNTs. (i) We elucidated the dominating role of alkyl side groups of polyfluorenes on their selective binding to SWCNTs of specific chiralities. These findings help to control post-synthetic methods for obtaining SWCNTs with certain chiralities and optoelectronic responses. (ii) Direct comparison of calculated and measured spectral features associated with emitting defect-states introduced to SWCNTs through low-level covalent functionalization allows us to explain experimental results from pump-dependent low-temperature photoluminescence spectroscopy and identify the role of the tube chirality and divalent functionalization in selective control of defect-associated emission of SWCNTs. This is a significant finding for understanding of SWCNT chemistry, which has not previously established a case for such binding selectivity. Our results demonstrate that manipulation of the tube chirality together with the polarity and bond character of molecular adducts is a practical strategy for precise tuning of light emission in functionalized SWCNTs.

Broader Impact

Research outcomes have established foundation for the novel material design for solar energy conversion, sensing, and quantum technologies. Our simulations confirmed the tremendous potential of defects introduced by covalent functionalization of SWCNTs in development of single-photon sources capable of operating at telecom-wavelengths at room temperature. Up to now, materials working as single photon emitters in telecom-wavelengths had to be cooled to cryogenic temperatures, limiting their ultimate applications. Covalent functionalization makes SWCNTs promising materials for quantum communications. Additional potential originates from a vast synthetic space available for functional molecules towards improving emission intensity, stability, and quantum response of SWCNTs, which our research addressed. This is a new area for applications of SWCNTs demonstrating their unique capabilities.   

The project produced more diversely trained STEM professionals equipped with the necessary skills to solve current challenges in developing new and advancing existing methods for simulating light-driven processes in nanomaterials. The PI/coPIs provided research training in computations in conjunction with experimentalists via established collaborations and student internships at Los Alamos National Lab. The project complemented educational and research experiences of both undergraduate and graduate students via mini-research projects introduced to undergraduate Physical Chemistry and graduate Computational Chemistry courses to foster student creative-thinking and communication skills. The project has a positive impact on the university infrastructure resulted in extensions and updates of computational recourses at NDSU-CCAST facilities. PI/coPIs organized and led several outreach events focused on science demonstrations for the middle and high school students (hold both at the school locations and NDSU campus), which helped to attract talented students to NDSU, help them in decisions about future careers, and popularized scientific way of thinking to students and their parents, thus improving scientific literacy of various social groups at ND and MN states.
